review_title: Do exactly what the boss says and don't suggest anything.
pros: Good salary and benefits, management pays for meals sometimes too
cons:
I resigned after 6 months and I was happy to leave. 

There was no onboarding program. There was no clarity on management expectations and what my role will look like. Things were constantly changing and there was no time for any proper communication. I didn't have a manager to report to for first 3 months, then a manager was hired who left after 3 months - he had no background in Instructional Design or Training. There was very high workload and work-life balance was not good. 

I requested for training and it was rejected even though the training was for a new type of ID work that was not discussed at the interview or documented in the job description. Lots of surprises, not very pleasant. 

As an ID, there was very little action taken based on best practices and data driven decision making. Decisions were made based on whatever the manager representing 'client' Samsung wanted. There was lots of micro aggression, no documented best practices and a top down approach focused on 'the client' manager instead of evidence based approach that shows what works and what doesn't work. 

If you are a fast paced worker who keeps quiet and does work exactly as the 'client' wants, then you're ok but if you ask questions or suggest other approaches, you may be subject to excessive criticism, passive aggressive behavior, blame game and abandonment.

review_title: Average workplace with Raj mindset, compromised culture and ethics
pros:
Easy worklife, decent pay, infact at senior levels you are overpaid to the value you bring.
Minimum outcome ownership, primarily execution checklist driven, so you can't go really wrong here.
Large scale of ops
cons:
A small scale re-purposing of East India Company culture having Korean C-levels, VPs and next level Indian leadership as Zamindars & Khan Bahadurs.
Leadership is not very industry celebrated and in general lacks spine and vision, with rare exceptions, and indulged into zamindari feuds on work, team and credit grab.
Exceptionally few relate to the place, trust leaders, company or other teams, and vice versa.
Employee audits by multiple teams are a constant and the most indulging part. Actually, this is a reasonable step by Koreans given the compromised work ethics observed over time.
Well HR can be better titled as Harassment Resources than human... Succinctly, to be on blacklists for any decent MNC and big Indian Corporates and can be easily replaced by standard chatbots for efficient ops and lesser demotivation to junta. They have won awards for getting folks to Office during Covid in May and maximizing attendance. In fact sister concern Cheil was bashed up on Social as employees lost life, although it was managed meticulously.
Search on and speak to inside folks.

review_title: Good as first job for fresh graduate
pros:
1. Accepts graduates from a wide range of study disciplines.
2. Offers permanent role, therefore comes with good benefits and prestige.
3. Provides a support system especially as a newcomer in the company.
4. The pay is definitely in a competitive range in the market.
cons:
1. The interview to get in is super tough, therefore, the expectations that come from being an MA is pretty high.
2. Career progression is not as guaranteed (not necessarily going to be promoted on a faster track, this is one possible misconception)
3. The branch acts as a sales and marketing arm of Samsung, therefore do not come in thinking you can do anything tech-related.
4. The work environment is very fast-paced, if you are in a busy department, either you are swamped with work/overworked OR are completely ignored because the seniors are too busy to train/guide you.

Documents/MOP are un-organize,. Try to find the people who last updated the document and/or latest document on his PC.

review_title: Samsung Australia is NOT a great collaborative work environment, you have been warned.
pros:
Samsung make amazing products but: 
* in Australia don't care about staff, partners or customers. Its about Revenue $ and Bonus time for SLT.
* They have limited green credentials as a manufacturer and should be doing more for the environment.
cons:
* With a deeply entrenched Korean expat Management system, there is zero opportunity for growth, ever.
* Senior Management Team who use bullying tactics and coercion on staff to achieve sales results to drive their quarterly bonus payouts.
* Male dominated environment complete with matching egos, there is little to no female leaders who are advocating change in the structure.
* While pay is average, you will hand over your soul in exchange and demanded of to compromise your ethics and morals daily, all to make $$$ and profits.
* Life work balance is non existent, forget about support if you have a family.
* No people care factor: During the pandemic, staff were not supported at all.
- Without so much as a phone call to check on my wellbeing, in multiple lockdowns from my direct manager. 
- Smartwatches were provided to staff in September21 but in exchange a linkedin social post was demanded by SLT "to show how much they care" on social media.
*The Korean Leadership view is that Australians are lazy. Don't work here if you are looking for a supportive organisation who invests in staff.
